channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pakistan Army Begins Ground Assault on Militants
item.description: After two weeks of air and artillery strikes during which over 500,000 people fled the area, soldiers moved into town in North Waziristan early Monday.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Andy Coulson to Face Retrial in Royal Phone Hacking Case
item.description: A jury failed to reach a verdict last week on charges that the former tabloid editor and spokesman for Prime Minister David Cameron illegally obtained royal telephone directories.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Andy Coulson, former editor of the News of the World, arriving at the Old Bailey courthouse in London on Monday.

item.title: China’s Antigraft Push Snares Most Senior Target Yet
item.description: In the most far-reaching public move so far in President Xi Jinping’s drive against corruption, the Communist Party leadership on Monday expelled a retired military commander.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: The Vienna Philharmonic Recalls World War I in Sarajevo
item.description: The Vienna Philharmonic chose its material carefully for a concert held in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, that remembered World War I.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: In Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, people watch a live broadcast of the Vienna Philharmonic across from City Hall.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Edmund Malesky on Vietnam and China
item.description: Mr. Malesky, an associate professor of political economy at Duke University, provides insights into the recent fraught relations between the two Asian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A Vietnamese flag in Hanoi with the words "Toward the East Sea," commonly called the South China Sea by English speakers. A Chinese oil rig in waters off the disputed Paracel Islands ignited violent protests in Vietnam in May.

item.title: Pistorius Was Not Mentally Ill at Time of Shooting, Psychiatrists Report
item.description: The prosecution had sought the examination to challenge the defense’s contention that psychological factors buttressed the case for acquittal or leniency.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Leaning on Thailand’s Junta
item.description: Sanctions against the junta could prove surprisingly effective in the push to restore democracy.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By PAVIN CHACHAVALPONGPUN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Shame on the Blair Blamers
item.description: Britain’s former prime minister has become a divisive figure, but that should not blind us to what he is actually right about.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: Feeble Inflation and Lending Persist in Euro Zone
item.description: Consumer prices rose 0.5 percent in the bloc in June, far below the official target, while private sector lending shrank, keeping pressure on the E.C.B.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Ends Animal Testing Rule for Some Cosmetics
item.description: The move was praised by animal rights advocates, who say it is an important step in reducing the use of lab animals in product testing.
item.category: Council of Fashion Designers of America
People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Despite Protests, China Official Calls Taiwan Trip a Success
item.description: Zhang Zhijun, the head of China’s Taiwan Affairs Office, cut short meetings on his final day on the island after protesters hit his bodyguards with paint.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Guards for the head of China's Taiwan Affairs Office were spattered with paint in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung.

item.title: World Cup 2014: With Júlio César’s Help, More Respect for Brazilians in Net
item.description: Long ridiculed with terms such as “chicken man” and “lettuce hands,” Brazilian goalkeepers received a huge boost when Júlio César helped propel his team past Chile and into the World Cup quarterfinals.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: In São Paulo, young goalkeepers train at Fechando o Gol (Closing the Goal), run by the former Brazilian keeper Zetti. The school is an anomaly in a land that often holds keepers in low esteem.

item.title: Andy Coulson to Face New Trial on Hacking Charges
item.description: Former News of the World editor Andy Coulson and the paper's former royal reporter Clive Goodman will face a retrial on charges stemming from the phone hacking case.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lens Blog: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
item.description: A century after the start of World War I, the trail blazed – and lessons learned – by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By CRAIG ALLEN
item.media:description: Ernest Brooks was the first official photographer to be appointed by the British military. He is shown somewhere on the Western Front with his Goerz Anschütz plate camera.

item.title: North Korea Plans to Indict Two Americans; Defies U.N. by Firing Ballistic Missiles
item.description: The official news agency said that the Americans would be tried on charges of committing “hostile acts,” a report that came a day after the country launched two missiles off its east coast.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A man in Seoul, South Korea, on Sunday watched a program showing a North Korean rocket in a military parade. Missiles fired by the North landed in waters between it and Japan on Sunday.

item.title: Gunmen Fire on Nigerian Churchgoers
item.description: It is believed that the attackers are members of the extremist group Boko Haram, which went on to Kautikari, where they shot villagers and burned down homes.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Boko Haram, a militant Islamist group, is suspected in attacks on Nigerian churches as well as other attacks, including one Friday in Bauchi on this hotel, which local reports called a brothel.

item.title: Netanyahu Says Security Control Is Vital in Any Accord
item.description: Pointing to the rise of Islamic extremism, the Israeli prime minister appeared to toughen his requirements, further dimming the prospects for renewed talks.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: After West Bank Kidnapping, 2 Mothers Embody a Divide
item.description: Israel’s security crackdown has raised questions about the asymmetry of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the value of lives on both sides.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Before Shooting in Iraq, a Warning on Blackwater
item.description: Not long after the security firm’s top manager in Iraq told a State Department investigator “that he could kill” him, an inquiry was abandoned. Weeks later, the firm’s guards killed 17 civilians in Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JAMES RISEN
item.media:description: Blackwater personnel escorting Paul Bremer, an American civil administrator, upon his arrival in Ramadi, Iraq, in March 2004.

item.title: Flawed Saudi Response Is Cited in Outbreak of the Middle East Virus MERS
item.description: Cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome have more than tripled since the end of 2013, leading health experts to cite grave flaws in the way Saudi health officials have handled the crisis.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: A camel market in Al-Thamama, Saudi Arabia. MERS infects camels and can spread to humans, possibly in raw camel milk.

item.title: New N.S.A. Chief Calls Damage From Snowden Leaks Manageable
item.description: The director of the National Security Agency, Adm. Michael S. Rogers, described the steps the agency is taking to ensure that no one else can download the information taken by Edward J. Snowden, a former defense contractor.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Adm. Michael S. Rogers, seen last month, says it is crucial to “ensure that the volume” of data stolen before “can’t be stolen again.”

item.title: As Sumo Wrestling Grows in the U.S., It’s Mostly Men on the Mats
item.description: Women’s combat sports have been on a good run in the United States, but sumo wrestling is still waiting to take off.
item.dc:creator: By MARY PILON

item.title: New Wave of African Writers With an Internationalist Bent
item.description: Novelists with ties to Africa are gaining prominence in the publishing world as they become more cosmopolitan, and America does, too.
item.dc:creator: By FELICIA R. LEE
item.media:description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie at the premiere, in Lagos, Nigeria, of the film “Half of a Yellow Sun,” based on her novel.

item.title: Noordwijk Journal: Awakening the ‘Dutch Gene’ of Water Survival
item.description: The dikes of the country’s water management system work so well that experts say they worry that citizens will begin to take staying dry for granted.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: On a beach in Noordwijk, the Netherlands, students competed to build a sand castle that could withstand the tide the longest.

item.title: Rubble in India Is Combed, and Builders Arrested
item.description: Two buildings collapsed over the weekend in New Delhi and Chennai, India, killing at least 21 people and trapping others in the debris, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: The search continued at the site of a 12-story building that collapsed on Saturday in Chennai, India. By Sunday evening, 11 bodies and 21 survivors had been found.
